articles.headline: Mass Release of Immigrants Is Tied to Impending Cuts
articles.snippet: Though the government has not dropped deportation cases against them, hundreds of detainees were freed on supervised release while court proceedings continue, officials said.
articles.abstract: Though the government has not dropped deportation cases against them, hundreds of detainees were freed on supervised release while court proceedings continue, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal immigration officials have released hundreds of detainees from detention centers around the country in recent days in a highly unusual effort to save money as automatic budget cuts loom in Washington, officials said Tuesday.

articles.headline: Justices Turn Back Challenge to Broader U.S. Eavesdropping
articles.snippet: A 5-4 decision saying the plaintiffs lacked standing to sue over monitoring of international phone calls and e-mails illustrated how hard it is to mount court challenges to a wide array of antiterrorism measures.
articles.abstract: A 5-4 decision saying the plaintiffs lacked standing to sue over monitoring of international phone calls and e-mails illustrated how hard it is to mount court challenges to a wide array of antiterrorism measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday turned back a challenge to a federal law that broadened the government’s power to eavesdrop on international phone calls and e-mails.

articles.headline: Hagel Approved for Defense in Sharply Split Senate Vote
articles.snippet: A narrow victory for Chuck Hagel, confirmed as defense secretary, raised questions about whether he would arrive a diminished leader as the Pentagon faces cuts.
articles.abstract: A narrow victory for Chuck Hagel, confirmed as defense secretary, raised questions about whether he would arrive a diminished leader as the Pentagon faces cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate confirmed Chuck Hagel as defense secretary on Tuesday after he survived a bruising struggle with Republicans. At the same time,President Obama’s nominee to be Treasury secretary moved closer to approval with bipartisan support, suggesting that the Republican blockade against the administration’s second-term nominees was beginning to ease.

articles.headline: Wall Street Pay Rises, for Those Who Still Have a Job
articles.snippet: The average cash bonus for people employed in New York City in the financial industry rose by roughly 9 percent, to $121,900, in 2012, the New York State comptroller said.
articles.abstract: The average cash bonus for people employed in New York City in the financial industry rose by roughly 9 percent, to $121,900, in 2012, the New York State comptroller said.

articles.headline: Post-Fukushima, Arguments for Nuclear Safety Bog Down
articles.snippet: A dispute is developing between the nuclear industry and regulators, and among the regulators themselves, about the necessity of more safeguards at power plants.
articles.abstract: A dispute is developing between the nuclear industry and regulators, and among the regulators themselves, about the necessity of more safeguards at power plants.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alarms sounded and lights flashed as control panel dials at a nuclear power plant in upstate New York warned that the power for safety equipment was failing. The room went dark until the emergency lights kicked in. But there was no reason to worry on this frozen winter morning.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: Italian Deadlock Rekindles Anxiety About Euro Zone
articles.snippet: The apparent political gridlock signaled by its elections raises new fears that the euro crisis may be far from over.
articles.abstract: The apparent political gridlock signaled by its elections raises new fears that the euro crisis may be far from over.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — The political gridlock in Italy revives a question that hasn’t been heard lately: Is the euro zone crisis really over?
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Medicare Needs Fixing, but Not Right Now
articles.snippet: New cost-saving methods have kindled hope among some scholars that Medicare could achieve savings just by cleaning out the health care system’s waste.
articles.abstract: New cost-saving methods have kindled hope among some scholars that Medicare could achieve savings just by cleaning out the health care system’s waste.
articles.lead_paragraph: What’s the rush? For all the white-knuckled wrangling over spending cuts set to start on Friday, the fundamental partisan argument over how to fix the government’s finances is not about the immediate future. It is about the much longer term: how will the nation pay for the care of older Americans as the vast baby boom generation retires? Will the government keep Medicare spending in check by asking older Americans to shoulder more costs? Should we raise taxes instead?

articles.headline: S.E.C. Nominee Tries to Allay Skepticism
articles.snippet: Mary Jo White, President Obama’s choice to lead the S.E.C., is telling Congress she can avoid conflicts of interest despite her long career on Wall Street.
articles.abstract: Mary Jo White, President Obama’s choice to lead the S.E.C., is telling Congress she can avoid conflicts of interest despite her long career on Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mary Jo White’s path to the Securities and Exchange Commission has reached a crucial juncture: the Congressional charm campaign.

articles.headline: Austerity Kills Government Jobs as Cuts to Budgets Loom
articles.snippet: The federal government is cutting back at a pace exceeded in the last half-century only by the military demobilizations after the Vietnam War and the cold war.
articles.abstract: The federal government is cutting back at a pace exceeded in the last half-century only by the military demobilizations after the Vietnam War and the cold war.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government, the nation’s largest consumer and investor, is cutting back at a pace exceeded in the last half-century only by the military demobilizations after the Vietnam War and the cold war.

articles.headline: Attacked at 19 by an Air Force Trainer, and Speaking Out
articles.snippet: Virginia Messick is the first victim of a sexual assault scandal at Lackland Air Force Base to discuss what she has endured.
articles.abstract: Virginia Messick is the first victim of a sexual assault scandal at Lackland Air Force Base to discuss what she has endured.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — After her Air Force training instructor raped Virginia Messick, a young recruit, he told her it was fun and they should do it again, she remembers. Then he threw her clothes at her and ordered her to take a shower.

articles.headline: Now Gathering in Rome, a Conclave of Fallible Cardinals
articles.snippet: A British cleric resigned over allegations of sexual advances, even as many other clerics accused of failing to remove clergymen linked to child sexual abuse gather to choose a new pope.
articles.abstract: A British cleric resigned over allegations of sexual advances, even as many other clerics accused of failing to remove clergymen linked to child sexual abuse gather to choose a new pope.
articles.lead_paragraph: The sudden resignation of the most senior Roman Catholic cardinal in Britain, who stepped aside on Monday in the face of accusations that he made unwanted sexual advances toward priests years ago, showed that the taint of scandal could force a cardinal from participating in the selection of a new pope.
